Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Situation2: They are listed as the sole speaker for this week's congregational sermon, and the community has publicized their topic.
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as Mr. Rahman’s voice rose, sharp and suspicious. “How do I know this isn’t a scam? I’ve been with your company for years!” My script fluttered uselessly in my hand. As a telemarketer, I was trained to handle objections, to reassure, to explain every detail until the customer felt safe. But my eyes kept darting to the clock. In less than an hour, I was expected at the mosque, where I was the only imam scheduled to deliver the Friday sermon. The topic—“Honesty in Daily Life”—had been announced all week. The congregation would be waiting, expecting guidance, expecting me. My manager’s voice echoed in my mind: “Don’t let a customer go unsatisfied.” But the community’s trust was also at stake. My heart pounded as I tried to focus on Mr. Rahman’s questions, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my full presence, each unwilling to wait.
